factoid: Napoleon was an adorer and courtier of Emperor Alexander.
Napoleon was the adorer and courtier of himself.
Napoleon asked whether the horses were ready for the general.
Napoleon told the general to use his horses because the general had a long way to go.
Balashëv took the letter.
The letter was the last letter Napoleon sent to Emperor Alexander.
All details of the interview were communicated to the Russian monarch.
The war began.
Prince Andrew had an interview with Pierre in Moscow.
Prince Andrew went to Petersburg to meet Anatole Kurágin.
Prince Andrew inquired about Kurágin in Petersburg, but Kurágin had already left the city.
Pierre warned his brother-in-law that Prince Andrew was following him.
Anatole Kurágin obtained an appointment from the Minister of War and joined the army in Moldavia.
Prince Andrew met Kutúzov in Petersburg.
Kutúzov was Prince Andrew's former commander and was always well disposed toward him.
Kutúzov suggested that Prince Andrew accompany him to the army in Moldavia.
Prince Andrew received an appointment on the headquarters staff.
Prince Andrew left for Turkey.
Prince Andrew did not think it proper to write to Kurágin and challenge him.
Prince Andrew believed that challenging Kurágin without a fresh cause might compromise Countess Rostóva.
Prince Andrew wanted to meet Kurágin personally to find a fresh pretext for a duel.
Prince Andrew failed to meet Kurágin in Turkey because Kurágin returned to Russia soon after Prince Andrew arrived.
Prince Andrew found life easier to bear in a new country amid new conditions.
Prince Andrew's betrothed broke faith with him, and he felt the more acutely the more he tried to conceal the effects.
The surroundings that had made Prince Andrew happy became trying to him.
Prince Andrew still prized freedom and independence more than before.
Prince Andrew could no longer think of the thoughts he had first had while gazing at the sky on the field of Austerlitz.
Those thoughts had later been enlarged upon with Pierre.
Those thoughts had filled his solitude at Boguchárovo, Switzerland, and Rome.
Prince Andrew dreaded recalling the thoughts and the bright boundless horizons they had revealed.
Prince Andrew was now concerned only with the nearest practical matters unrelated to his past interests.
Prince Andrew seized on practical matters more eagerly as his past interests closed to him.
Army service was the simplest and most familiar activity for Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew applied himself to business with zeal and perseverance as a general on duty on Kutúzov’s staff.
Prince Andrew surprised Kutúzov with his willingness and accuracy in work.
Prince Andrew did not think it necessary to rush back to Russia after Kurágin.
Prince Andrew knew that when he met Kurágin he would not be able to resist calling him out.
The consciousness that the insult was not yet avenged and his rancor was still unspent weighed on Prince Andrew's heart.
The consciousness poisoned the artificial tranquility Prince Andrew obtained in Turkey through restless, plodding, vainglorious, and ambitious activity.
In 1812, news of the war with Napoleon reached Bucharest.
Kutúzov had been living in Bucharest for two months, spending his days and nights with a Wallachian woman.
Prince Andrew asked Kutúzov to transfer him to the Western Army.
Kutúzov was weary of Bolkónski’s activity, which seemed to reproach his own idleness.
Kutúzov readily let Prince Andrew go and gave him a mission to Barclay de Tolly.
